summary: When cancelling a workflow coroutine that contains an `awaitWithTimeout()` call, execution incorrectly continues to subsequent async tasks after the timeout is cancelled, instead of respecting the cancellation and stopping.
userImpact: Developers cannot reliably cancel workflow coroutines containing timeout operations, as code continues executing after the timeout is cancelled.
rootCause: When restoring context after a cancelled timer, the code does not check whether the coroutine itself was cancelled before returning to it, allowing subsequent async tasks to execute.
proposedFix: Before entering a coroutine after cancelling a timer, check whether the coroutine is cancelled and skip execution if it is.
workaround: Replace `awaitWithTimeout()` with `await()` to avoid the issue, though this removes timeout functionality.
keyQuote: Before entering the coroutine we should check whether it is cancelled or not.
